What is MLapis?
MLapis translates ML documents into .
What good is ML?
http://www.latex-project.org/http://www.latex-project.org/ is very good at a number of very tricky things. These include formatting mathematical formulae, laying out out books and articles, typesetting text and tables in a pleasing and consistant manner, etc. However, XML is good at a number of things is not so good at, such as being easily parsed and translated into a variety of output formats.
Unfortunately, the standard XML transformation system XSLhttp://www.w3.org/Style/XSL/http://www.w3.org/Style/XSL/ is not powerful enough to translate from normal XML formats to directly. So when you use XML to edit, store, and distribute your source documents, ML provides the bridge you need to leverage the power of when formatting your document for the printed page.
The DTD and other documentation about MLhttp://www.alphaworks.ibm.com/formula/texmlhttp://www.alphaworks.ibm.com/formula/texml is available from IBM alphaWorkshttp://www.alphaworks.ibm.com/formula/texmlhttp://www.alphaworks.ibm.com/formula/texml. My interpretation of their software license does not allow me to redistribute those materials here.
MLapis vs. MLatte
There is already a ML-to- translator called MLattehttp://www.alphaworks.ibm.com/formula/texmlhttp://www.alphaworks.ibm.com/formula/texml, but I was completely unable to get it to work. It's written in Javahttp://java.sun.com/http://java.sun.com/ and the perhaps the runtime engines I have around are drastically sub-standard or something, but for whatever reason I could not get their tool to run. Also, the software license for
MLatte is rather less community-oriented than the GPL, so I thought a new implementation was in order.
MLapis is written in pure Perl 5 and requires nothing but a standard Perlhttp://www.cpan.org/ports/http://www.cpan.org/ports/ interpreter. It has it's own little XML parser built in. Of course in order for it to be useful you'll need at least and almost certainly an XSLT processor as well. It was written entirely without reference to the MLatte code, which I have never even seen, so there shouldn't be any copyright entanglements. I cannot guarantee that it will produce results identical to MLatte, but it has worked well enough for my purposes and seems to comply with available specs and examples.
